chief_complaint: 5-day history of a febrile illness, presenting with fever and shock.
history_of_present_illness: The illness started with fever, sore throat, and aching all over. She also developed abdominal pain and diarrhoea. She became increasingly unwell, very weak, and needed help to stand.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Her husband died of a severe febrile illness 6 days before she became ill. He had worked in a local gold mine and had fallen ill about a week before his death. She had looked after him during his final illness at home.
vitals: Blood pressure 85/65mmHg, pulse rate 105 bpm, temperature 38°C (100.4°F).
physical_exam: Looks very unwell. Bilateral conjunctivitis. No rash, no lymphadenopathy. Heart sounds are normal. Chest is clear. Abdominal examination is normal.
labs_and_diagnostics: Malaria slide showed a low level of parasitaemia with P. falciparum. A sample for Marburg and Ebola PCR was sent. Marburg virus PCR result was positive.
differential_diagnosis: Malaria, typhoid fever, bacterial sepsis (including invasive meningococcal disease), severe viral infection (adenovirus, influenza), measles, Zika virus, viral haemorrhagic fever (VHF), Marburg virus disease (MVD).
management_and_clinical_course: Presumed diagnosis of Marburg virus disease was made. Isolated in a side room with contact carried out wearing gloves. Treated with IV artesunate and then artemether/lumefantrine. Given empirical IV ceftriaxone and resuscitated with IV fluids. Remained very unwell for a few days, then started to improve. Kept in isolation for an additional 2 days post-recovery before discharge. Family members, close friends, and medical staff who had physical contact were monitored for temperature for 21 days.
final_diagnosis: Marburg virus disease (MVD), confirmed by positive PCR.
